title: 106_s456
content: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section, SEC. 45D, which allows for credits related to information technology training program expenses. The new section SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a 20% credit for information technology training program expenses paid by an employer. An additional 5 percentage points can be added for expenses incurred in designated empowerment zones, enterprise communities, or school districts with a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. The new section SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a 20% credit for information technology training program expenses paid by an employer. An extra 5 percentage points can be added for expenses in designated empowerment zones, enterprise communities, or school districts with a high percentage of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches. The new section SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a 20% credit for information technology training program expenses paid by an employer, with an additional 5% for expenses in specific zones or districts. The maximum amount of eligible expenses for an individual in a taxable year is $6,000. Information technology training program expenses include costs related to participating in such programs for computer programmers, systems analysts, and computer scientists or engineers. The new section SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a 20% credit for information technology training program expenses paid by employers, with an additional 5% for specific zones or districts. The maximum eligible expenses for an individual in a taxable year is $6,000. Certified commercial information technology training providers are private sector providers of educational products and services used for IT training. The new section SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 provides a 20% credit for information technology training program expenses paid by employers. Small employers are defined as those with 200 or fewer employees. No double benefit deduction or credit is allowed for these expenses. The new section SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a 20% credit for information technology training program expenses. Rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52 apply. The credit is part of the general business credit under section 38(b), and no carrybacks are allowed for the section 45D credit before the effective date. The unused business credit for any taxable year related to the information technology training program credit cannot be carried back to a year before the enactment of section 45D. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by section 45D regarding information technology training program expenses apply to expenses incurred after the enactment date in taxable years ending after that date.
